content: The text chunk discusses the permanent extension of the research credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with amendments to Section 41 and Section 45C(b)(1). The effective date for these amendments is after June 30, 1998. Additionally, it mentions an improved alternative incremental credit in Section 2. The text chunk introduces an election for an alternative incremental credit under Section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, with modifications to the base amount calculation. The base period for calculating the taxpayer's gross receipts is defined, with exceptions for minimum base amounts. Start-up and small taxpayers have a minimum gross receipts amount of $1,000,000. The base period is the 8-taxable year period before the current year. Qualified research is also mentioned. Qualified research, for the purposes of reporting to shareholders, partners, or for credit purposes, excludes certain types of research as defined in subsection (d)(4). The treatment of such research is subject to financial accounting standards. The treatment of expenditures as research and development costs must align with Financial Standards No. 2. Significant changes in accounting standards require notification to the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. The treatment of expenditures as research and development costs aligns with Financial Standards No. 2. Significant changes in accounting standards require notification to the House Ways and Means Committee and the Senate Finance Committee. Changes in tax regulations may not affect taxable years before a specified date. Taxpayers can elect to exclude certain years from the calculation of the base amount. An election under this subsection applies to the year made and subsequent years unless revoked with the Secretary's consent. The Secretary provides assistance to small and start-up businesses. The Secretary of the Treasury provides assistance to small and start-up businesses to comply with IRS section 41 requirements and reduce compliance costs. An amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is made, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1998. MODIFICATIONS TO CREDIT FOR BASIC RESEARCH. The text chunk discusses the elimination of the incremental requirement for basic research payments under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Amendments are made to sections 41(a)(2) and 41(e) of the Code to determine the amount of basic research payments for the taxable year. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 regarding basic research payments. Subparagraphs are redesignated, and specific commercial objectives are defined for research purposes. Expansion of the research tax credit to include federal laboratories under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Innovation Act of 1980 (15 U.S.C. 3703(6)) is effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 1998. SEC. 4. CREDIT FOR EXPENSES ATTRIBUTABLE TO CERTAIN COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH CONSORTIA. The amendment to section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a 20 percent credit for amounts paid to a qualified research consortium. A qualified research consortium is defined as an organization described in section 501(c)(3). Organization described in section 501(c)(3) exempt from tax under section 501(a), primarily conducts scientific or engineering research, not a private foundation, received amounts from at least 15 unrelated persons for research, no more than 50% of total amounts from 3 unrelated persons for research. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 1998, for scientific or engineering research organizations. Persons treated as a single employer under certain sections are considered related persons for specific purposes.
